entry.title: Indonesia - From Bali to Lombok
entry.content:
I love everything about Komodo and Scuba Junkie Komodo so I was really sad leaving, but it was time to meet up with Sarah and do some exploring around Bali and Lombok.

Bali is an extremely busy Island full of Aussies that has been buying land there for over a decade pushing land prices through the roof (Lombok is also getting there, if not already, especially around Kuta). However there are still some places around both islands that are pretty quiet and undeveloped.

We started in Denpasar but only stayed there for two nights. We stayed in Jimbaran and explored the Jimbaran Bay area during the day and later we met up with my good friends Deb, John, Daniel & Mathias for a few beers. We left Jimbaran the day after and headed for Ubud.

We stayed in Ubud for a couple of days. During our stay we went on a bicycle tour down the mountain with a company called Ring A Bike Tour. We were privately guided by a local called Jering who’s very knowledgeable and friendly. He took good care of us and delivered some excellent details about Ubud and it’s history. We also managed to visit the “Monkey Forest” (Note to self : Do not treat the monkeys as pets, they will bite) before it was time to head over to Amed, Tulamben and the Liberty Wreck.

In Amed we stayed at a posh hotel for two days. I got to enjoy some excellent diving at the Liberty Wreck (which is easily the best wreck dive I’ve done so far) and Sarah tried some snorkeling. Before leaving to Padang Bai and Lombok we also rented motorbikes and went up in the mountain along the coastline for some excellent views.

We didn’t really spend any time in Padang Bai, we just used it as an overnight stop before leaving Bali. We took the public ferry from Padang Bai (Bali) to Lembar (Lombok). The ferry takes about 4-6 hours depending on god knows what. It’s like everything else in Asia, it’s simply “Asian time”, it differs from day to day.

We headed to the secluded Selong Belanak and enjoyed a few days at the beach. The beach is simply stunning and probably one of the most beautiful beaches I’ve seen on this trip. Interestingly enough we were basically the only ones there since it’s the rain season now. The rain season (or wet season as they refer to it) is basically between October and April, however I haven’t seen much of this rain. Nevertheless, we had a good time in Selong Belanak and I can definitely recommend staying here for a few days. There is only a few accommodations available, nothing directly on the beach, but just a few hundred away there is a place called Selong Belanak Bungalows who provides simple bungalows for a fair price.

Next up is Gili Gede, Senggigi, Nusa Lembongan and who knows!

entry.title: Komodo National Park - Amazing Diving With Amazing People
entry.content:
When leaving Mabul I wasn’t really sure where to go. My choices basically stood between Kalamantan and Komodo National Park. Since I already done 25 dives in Komodo National Park one could think that I would like to try diving elsewhere.

However, as the topic suggests, I went back to Komodo National Park, mainly because of the amazing diving and the amazing people, it’s actually very hard to beat this combo. The last time I was here I dove with Scuba Junkie Komodo and I can’t think of any better way to diving in Komodo, nor can I think of any better people to spend time with - their resort & staff is simply perfect.

  • Carrys & Rohan - Your resort and proffesionalism is amazing, keep up the good work.
  • Deb & John - You’re the best diveinstructors I’ve come across, I’ll make sure we’ll dive together again.
  • Solemon, Fandi & Yadi - You’re all amazing divemasters, I’ll make sure we’ll dive together again.
  • Max, Jeremy, Matthias, Mathew & Erin - Good luck as divemasters, I’m sure you’ll do great.
  • Davey - Thanks for all your detailed knowledge about fish life, I’m sure you’ll do a great job at the resort.
  • Rest of the staff - You’re great, you made my time at Scuba Junkie Komodo very memorable.
Thanks again Scuba Junkie Komodo - see you when I see you.
Who knows, maybe I'll become your next dive master student.

entry.title: Mabul & Sipadan - to Busy and Heavily Overpriced
entry.content:
I decided to leave Manila and head over to Borneo for a second time. This time I really wanted to try out Sipadan and the diving around Mabul. Sipadan is probably one of the most famous dive destinations in Asia and its dive site Baracuda Point is well known amongst divers. Needless to say I had high expectations about Sipadan.

The thing that threw me off a little bit the last time I was on Borneo was the recent cases of kidnapping on Mabul and the recommendation “not to go there” from the Swedish Embassy. As rescent as last year one police officer killed got killed and another kidnapped so I think it’s only natural to have second thoughts about going there. After reading up about it though I felt pretty safe going there.

I headed off to Kota Kinabalu and spent the day there with some good friends. Later that night I flew off to Sandakan and spent the night at the airport. Now, sleeping at the airport is not as comfy as it sounds, it’s actually rather the opposite. I did however managed to sleep a few hours on a “steel bench” with my laundry bag as a pillow and catch my early morning flight to Tawau. My good friend Fizzy had ordered a pickup for me at the airport so the transfer from Tawau to Semporna was a breeze. I waited a few hours in Semporna and then finally we headed off to Mabul

Directly when we arrived at Mabul I got the feeling that this wasn’t the place for me. It’s extremely crowded and everything is very “robotic”, there is no “personal touch” to the place. It’s just way to busy for me, and you are “just one in the crowd”. I tend to like the abandoned places with as few people as possible. Fizzy had booked a few nights for me at a local homestay called “Panglima” which I enjoyed very much. Almost every day we had lunch at a local place that served some excellent kway teow. I had so many kway teow there that in the end I didn’t even had to order, I just looked at the waiter, smiled and nodded. A few days later we found a local börger place who served some excellent “double deluxe beef börgers” - we were living the high life.

The diving around Mabul didn’t really impress me. Again, it’s very crowded, the water is “greenish” and the visibility was far from great. With that being said though, I saw some cool stuff so I definitely not regret going there. But one, maximum two days of diving was enough for me.

Now, Sipadan is a different story. Sipadan is far from crowded, the island is clean and the visibility in the water is generally good (it wasn’t amazing during my four dives, but around 20m). The diving itself was alright, but I definitely wouldn’t rate it as one of my favourite dive sites. We saw quite a few white tip sharks, a huge school of jacks (this was actually really cool, a huge wall of jacks, literally thousands of thousands), a small school of barracudas (unfortunately we never saw the huge school of barracudas that barracuda point is so famous for), turtles, giant trevallys, school of bumphead parrotfish, and some beautiful scenery (if you’re lucky you’ll even get to see the hammerheads as well (I wasn’t though)).

So, why isn’t this my favourite dive site when it seems to be everyone else’s ? I’ve spoken to dive masters who literally has done over thousand dives at this place and just loves it. And this is exactly my point. A thousand dives is of course extreme, but since this is nature we are talking about (the visibility, the amount of fishes, the types of fishes etc.) I would need at least a few days of fun diving to be able to rate it “my favourite dive site”. Maybe I had a bad day at Sipadan, but I’ll never know for sure since I basically “can’t go there again”. Of course I can visit Sipadan, it’s not physically impossible, but the prices are just ridiculous. You’re looking at between 800-1000 ringit for one day diving around Sipadan, and that’s only for the day at Sipadan, most operators wont take you to Sipadan unless you do a couple of days fun diving with them around Mabul/Kapalai. The execution here is just terrible, but I don’t blame anyone, nor do I have a suggestion on how to do it better, it’s just a tough situation when the whole world wants to come together and dive and at the same spot, at the same time you’re trying to protect mother earth.

So far my favorite diving destinations in Asia is,

  1. Komodo National Park, Indonesia. This is without a doubt my favorite place so far. For more information see my previous post
  2. Apo Reef, Philippines. This is right behind number Komodo. Komodo National Park is more diverse and therefore I rate it higher. But I highly doubt that you’ll regret goint to Apo Reef. Check out my earlier post for more information.

entry.title: Manila - an Interesting City That Is Often Overlooked
entry.content:
After coming back from Anilao I decided to stay in Manila for a few days, partly because I wanted to be there for Gen (who just lost her cat), but also to bust the myths about Manila and the Filipino food. When you read about the Philippines in Lonely Planet, or any other travel guide for that matter, they always tell you two things. Firstly, get out of Manila as fast as you can, secondly the Filipino food stinks (it may not be written that harsh, but when you talk to people this is the general opinion).

Since this is my second time in the Philippines I thought I would try to see if there was some truth to these statements. The last time I was here I only “stayed” in Manila over the night and got out of the city the morning after so I wasn’t really paying to much attention to the city itself. With that being said though, I still saw some parts of the city. It was extremely busy and very “torn down” (loads of “broken houses”, trashes everywhere and a lot of poverty areas). Since this was barely six months ago nothing really regarding the city itself has changed. However, this time I enter Manila with a different perspective and a few more days to really explore the city.

Manila is an extremely busy city. The population of the city is actually “only” around 1.6 million, but that is on an area that is only ~40km2 (that gives us ~43000 people per km2), compare that to London for example (that is considered to be a busy city) that has around 8.5 million people on area that is ~1600km2 (that gives us “only” ~5500 people per km2). And this is actually only the “city”, if we include the metro and urban areas we get a population around 24 million people (the density in those areas are ~18000 respectively ~15000). If we include the same areas around London we get a population around 32 million people (and a density in the metro area that is around 1600 respectively 5600 in the urban area). Point being, there is a lot of people in the Philippines living in a cramped up area. Now bear in mind that the Philippines isn’t really a “rich” country, so they have a very poor infrastructure and limited possibilities to make the situation better. The area around Manila is simply very, very busy - no doubt about it.

Traveling in Manila is a nightmare since the traffic situation is just crazy (again, to much people and lack of proper infrastructure). There are a few places on earth were the traffic is this bad, Bombay in India is one of them I hear. The traffic is literally insane. Sometime if the traffic is bad it can take up to two hours to travel 10 km (you can walk faster than that). Not only that there is a lot of pollution from all the jeepneys, and recently there has been an increase of the “robbing passengeres crime” so you’re actually recommended to keep your doors closed.

Now, if we disregard these two annoyances mentioned above, Manila is actually a quite interesting city with some cool history. I’ve already mentioned Carlos Celdran and his take on the history of the Philippines in this post (at the end). This time we went on a tour called The Big Binondo Food Wok. This tour is about three hours long and consists of walking around in the area called Binondo, also referred to as Manilas Chinatown. Binondo is actually the worlds oldest Chinatown and was established in 1594. During the tour you have five food stops were you get to try some old Chinese food. I recommend that you have an empty stomach while taking this tour since there will be a lot of food.

In the The Big Binondo Food Wok we tried,

  • Pancit Canton, noodles with beef, chicken or whatever
  • Fried Chicken, some local fried chicken recipe
  • Hotteok, sugary pancakes
  • Hopia, soft cookie-dough filled with ube (can be filled with whatever)
  • Lumpia, a fried sugary roll
  • Tokwa, fried tofu
  • Kiamoy, a dried plum
  • Pork Dumplings, minced meat & chopped vegetables wrapped into a piece of dough skin

As for the rest of my stay in the Philippines I tried, among other things,

  • Sizzling Sisig, parts of a pig’s head and liver, served on a sizzling plate
  • Cebu Lechon, pork
  • Liempo, pork belly
  • Adobong Manok, meat marinated in vinegar, soy sauce and garlic
  • Champorado, chocolate rice porridge
  • Callos, beef stew
  • Ossobuco, cross-cut veal shanks braised with vegetables, white wine and broth

To avoid confusion,

  Means that I liked it.
  Means that it was okay, maybe nothing I would order again.
  Means that I tasted it, but disliked it quite much.
  Means that I didn’t taste it for various reasons.

Also, of course to make my dear friend and colleague Rafael Urrutia happy I tried a lot of börgers. Same as in Sweden, a lot of hipster places is popping up all over Manila serving some awesome börgers, my favorite place was a place called snack shack börger. Also tried 8 cuts börger, ironically enough I didn’t really think their börgers cut it. Last but not least I had some insanely good ribs at this place called racks.

So to sum it up, I enjoyed my stay in Manila. I definitely think there are quite a few cultural places with an interesting history worth visiting. There is also a lot of Filipino food worth trying, so don’t be to scared from the rumors. The city is crowded for sure, but if you just make sure to include the traffic in your daily plan you’re all good.

The Philippines is one of my favorite countrys in Asia, I seriously do love these beatuiful Islands filled with all these nice and generous people. This particular post is about Manila, and even though I enjoyed Manila, I definitely prefer the island life. One day I will have my diving resort on one of these islands.

entry.title: Spending My Birthday in Anilao - the Posh Way
entry.content:
To celebrate my birthday last week me and Gen decided (in last minute) to get ourselves to Anilao. A popular macro diving site located only “three hours” away from Manila. Three hours Filipino time that is. You probably can make it in three hours if you decide to go with a private transport, however if you go with the local transport including a bus ride, a jeepney ride and finally a tricycle ride, you’re probably looking at 5 hours minimum.

There are several bus companies that does daily routes down to Batangas City, we chose the one called Jam Liner and paid roughly 125 php per person. When you arrive at the bus station in Batangas City you simply switch to one of the jeepneys going to Mabini (another 35 php per person). Be sure to tell the driver that you are going to Anilao so he can drop you off at the “the crossing” where you would continue the last part with a tricycle for about 120 php.

Even though I’m fully capable of carrying my own bag, this little kid insisted on helping me carry my bag from the bus to the jeepney. It was only about fifty meters and I told him several times that I would carry my own bag. Around half way he gave up, and I continued to the jeepney. Later when I was joking around with the jeepney-drivers the kid snuck up on me and lifted my bag into the jeepney. I laughed for my self and gave the boy some money. I would have loved to give him credit for his quick-witted mind but he disappeared. I like to think that this boy is going places if anybody just gave him the chance. Unfortunately the world is tough and far from everyone gets the chance they deserve.

We arrived quite late to this resort called Halo Anilao Dive Resort located far from the busy streets life of Anilao. The resort itself isn’t anything special, I mean the rooms were nice and the food was good, but the place it self was kind of “meh”. It kinda threw me off a bit, and we only stayed there one night. The next day we decided to go all in and chose a place called La Chevrerie Resort & Spa (after all, my sister told me to “spoil myself” since I’m always so stingy, I however consider myself as an economic person, I’ll leave it up for discussion though).

La Chevrerie Resort & Spa is a fantastic resort in every aspect, the rooms were amazing, the food was gorgeous, the view was stunning and the staff was extremely helpful and friendly. The only thing I could say something about is the price, but I guess you get what you pay for. And there are far more expensive resorts out there, but yes, La Chevrerie Resort & Spa did leave some sort of whole in my wallet ;)

The plan was to stay in the area for a couple of days, but we cancelled the holiday since Gen’s cat unfortunately passed away. Her name was Ate Guy (pronounced “ah-teh-guy”) and we brought her to the veterinarian two days earlier since she hadn’t been eating for a while and was very weak. The veterinarian did what they could and gave her antibiotics, but after two days Ate Guy sadly passed away. Gen rescued Ate Guy from the streets about seven years ago, during these years Ate Guy has had the best possible life. I’m sure Ate Guy has her place in cat heaven by now.

❤

I'm glad I got to meet Ate Guy just in time. Such a sweet cat.
Here she is cuddling with me right before our trip.

entry.title: Apo Reef - Simply Stunning
entry.content:
Last time I went to the Philippines I really wanted to go to the famous Apo Reef, but my stinginess actually kept me from going there. This time though I was really determined to get my ass over there. It’s a little bit tricky to get to Apo Reef, but trust me, it’s definitely worth the effort.

Now, the tricky part is actually to find a way to get to the reef itself. Since it’s located south-east of the island Mindoro not to many dive shops operate the reef, nor is there a quick easy way to get to any of the shops that do. You basically have two options, either you go with a dive shop in Coron, or you go by one located on Mindoro. I definitely recommend Apo Reef Club located about one hour south of Sablayan on Mindoro. Apo Reef Club is a professional dive shop run by Micheal Roos and has been doing trips to Apo Reef for about eight years now.

The easiest way to get to Apo Reef Club is to take a flight from Manila to San Jose and then ask Apo Reef Club for a pickup in San Jose. The flight from Manila departs roughly three times a week, so be sure to make your booking in time. However, if you feel a little bit more adventures you can take the one of the buses from Manila down to Batangas and from there try to find your own way over to Mindoro and down to San Jose. Or, you could take the famous Dimplestar Bus which will take you all the way. I chose the latter and went with the Dimplestar all the way from Manila to Apo Reef Club (the bus line is actually going all the way to San Jose, but Apo Reef Club is located north of San Jose, so you’ll have to get off in a small “town” called Concepcion, where Apo Reef Club will pick you up). Note, you’ll also have to tell Dimplestar that you are going either to Apo Reef Club or to Sablayan. It’s probably safer to say Sablayan, because they might not know Apo Reef Club. The reason you have to mention this is because there is two ways to San Jose, one is passing Sablayan and Apo Reef Club, the other one is not (it’s taking the east route of Mindoro, and you don’t want to get stuck in San Jose).

With that being said, prepare yourself for a 13 hour long bus ride, including several hundred stops, a delayed and very slow ferry, the bumpiest road you’ll ever experience and some extremely loud fucking techno music. If thats what you fancy and you’ve only got 800 php to spend on the ride, this is the way to go. Otherwise, just take the god damn flight to San Jose - I’m for sure not doing that nightmare bus ride ever again. And yes, there is some sort of schedule with these buses, but as everything else in the Philippines it may vary from day to day so you better call them and ask first. Oh, the phone numbers doesn’t really work either so you better get your ass to the bus station and ask the guy behind the counter; welcome to the Philippines ;)

Enough ranting on how to get there, here’s the goodies about Apo Reef. Apo Reef is the world’s second-largest contiguous coral reef system and the largest in the Philippines. It houses 385 species of colorful marine fishes including families of sharks (including hammerheads if it’s the right season), stingrays, mantas (seasonal), school of jacks, snappers, barracudas, mackerels, and green humphead parrotfish, swarms of tropical aquarium fish, blennies and gobies. The visibility is above anything I’ve ever seen before. I did eleven dives at the reef and we had 40m+ visibility on every dive (if you aren’t a diver, you can literally just snorkel - visibility is that good). The thing that really blew me away (except the stuff mentioned above) was that the reef wasn’t crowded with divers, not a single one actually, it’s only you, your buddies and the fishes - it’s extremely cool.

Here’s a quote from me describing it on facebook, “Imagine a pool (you know, where you have a visibility of 40m+). And then you add every freaking colorful fish you can think of. And then throw in some sharks, some mackerel, some humpheads, some barracudas, and yeah throw in some turtles while you’re at it. Of course don’t forget about the incredible beautiful scenery (big walls etc). Then you multiply that imagination by a hundred and maybe, only maybe, you come close to apo reef. So, yes, even if the thirteen hour ride here was one of the worst ever, it was worth it. That school of humpheads is just the craziest shit I ever seen.”

Apo Reef is simply stunning and definitely one of my favourite dive sites.

entry.title: Malapascua - Paradise Island With the Thresher Sharks
entry.content:
Malapascua is the name of an island north of Cebu in the Central Visayas region in the Philippines. It’s a quite small island mostly known for its diving and the “guarantee” of seeing the famous thresher sharks. Malapascua is definitely worth a visit and it’s actually not that tricky to get there, its just like everything else in the Philippines; you’ve got to have patiense and a lot of time

Easiest way to get in is to take a flight (depending on where you comning from that is) to Cebu city and then arrange for a private ride (van/taxi) to a city called Maya. This is of course the most expensive option, the private ride will probably set you back around 1800 - 2500 php depending on your bargaining skills , but with that being said, it’s also definitely the fastest option. The cheaper alternative is to go to the “north bus station” in Cebu city and take the local bus that leaves about four times per day. That ride will only cost you around 160 php, but could be quite long (mine took almost six hours) so be sure to bring entertainment.

No matter which alternative you choose, you will end up at the port in Maya city. From there it’s only a short boat ride (about 20 minutes) until you reach Malapascua island. Transfer boats leave regularly (between 6am - 6pm) and cost 80 php. If the tide is low, you will have to pay for a small “transfer boat” which will cost you 20 php (this is 20 php on the Maya side, and another 20 php at the Malapascua side). They will try to make you pay a lot more, but just ask the locals how much they pay and tell the boat man that you want the same price as them.

When you’re finally on the actual island you will have tons of resorts, dive centers and cheap bungalow accommodations. I went for a private bungalow, right on the beach next to my diving center for only 700 php per night. My stay was during the “low season” though so be prepared to pay up to 1200 for these bungalows (the place I stayed at was called “Dannio’s” or something similar, I had hard time with that name). As for the diving I went with a place called Evolution, a very professional shop located at the end of the beach. There are tons of options so I recommend just walking around and grab the one you’re most comfortable with. If you do two dives in one day that will cost you somewhere around 2600 php and upwards, depending on your choosing.

I had a great stay at Evolution and made a lot of new friends. Evolution really takes care of you and makes you feel at home. They are running a very professional dive shop, with good dive masters, good equipment and good briefings, everything is simply top notch. Diving with the thresher sharks is simply stunning and definitely the main attraction, however make sure not to miss all the macro stuff.

Mustafa, Seden, Carlo and Freedom, you will always have room in my hostel heart. Until next time, Mustafa and Carlo, make sure to take good care of your better halves ;)

❤

entry.title: Coron - Island Paradise
entry.content:
As I mentioned in my previous post I got my mind set on Coron and some Wreck diving this time in the Philippines, at least to begin with.

We decided to stay in Coron town for two nights, just to get our bearings straight before deciding where in Coron to actually stay the rest of the week. That was probably two nights to much. Coron is a really small shitty busy town with tricycles and roosters everywhere. Get the hell out as quick as you can.

The main reason to go to Coron is the famous wreck diving, which is exactly the reason I went there. I wasn’t really sure if wreck diving was my thing or not, I had the feeling it wasn’t, but the only way to know for sure was to actually try it. Turns out my feeling was right. I did three dives on three different wrecks, and I while it is truly awesome to swim through old ships (like the engine room, old cabins, the bridge, the ballast tanks, etc) I still prefer really good visibility and beautiful reefs. With that being said though, seeing the “12.7 cm/40 Type 89 Naval Gun” at 33 meters on the ship ‘Akitsushima’ is really, really cool.

After my diving we practically didn’t do a thing. We just stayed at our island resort and enjoyed the good weather and the beautiful scenery. We did a short “island hopping” one day to explore the snorkeling and the nearby beaches. The islands and the nature around Coron/Palawan is truly something special. I would definitely recommend you to go there if you are in the Philippines.

Tomorrow I’ll leave for Malapascua to do some diving with the thresher sharks, sadly I’ll have to leave Gen behind for a while since she got caught up in work. Luckily I got to spend the last day following Gen at her work, as a tv producer, watching while she and her crew were shooting a cooking show - heaps of fun.

I love the Philippines <3

entry.title: Forget All You Thought You Knew About Diving
entry.content:
It has been over two weeks since my last update so I figured a new one would be in place. This time it will be all about diving <3

With my buoyancy pretty much under control and over 40 dives I figured I knew at least the basics about the underwater world (such as turtle’s, white/black tipped sharks, puffer fishes, trigger fishes, nudis, moray eels, etc.). Turns out that I had seen nothing. Literally nothing compared to what you will see if you go to Komodo National Park. The park is huge (total area of 1,733 km²) and the diving is so diverse that you wouldn’t believe it.

Even though this is a very popular diving destination the coral reefs are very healthy (and extremely stunning) and the fishes are just amazing. The visibility is often > 15 meters so you got nothing to complain on there. If there would be something negative about Komodo National Park it basically boils down to two things,

  • The average temperature is between 26 - 28 which usually means that you would want to wear a wetsuit. It’s really nothing weird with that, it’s just that I usually prefer diving without a suit.

  • Some days, at some dive sites, the current can be incredibly strong. Probably the strongest you ever felt. This can be quite fun, since you get to see a lot of “action”, it can also be your worst experience ever. Personally I prefer the calmer dives, even though I appreciate the experience I get from the “crazy, current dives”. Note, there is a big difference between what I call “a crazy, current dive” and a “regular, drift dive”. “Regular drift dives are fine and usually very cool, "crazy, current dives” are, well, crazy.

I stayed with a large group of friends at the newly opened Scuba Junkie Komodo Beach Resort and had a fantastic time. The resort is managed by the dive instructors Rohan and Carys whose professionalism is far beyond anything I’ve come across before. Everything, such as, staff, guidance, equipment, accommodation, food, etc. is extremely professional. Scuba Junkie really got a good thing going here, and I will definitely return - no doubts.

The initial plan was to do four days of diving (three dives per day), but after the second day at a dive site called the couldran I decided, right there and then (seriously, the diving is that good), to extend my stay and do another four days of diving. Totally I ended up with 24 dives in the park and a lot of new friends, both under water and above =)

After Indonesia and Komodo I headed over to the Philippines to meet my friend Gen for some awesome diving and exploring. Since this is my second time in the Philippines I pretty much got my route clear on what I want to do this time, starting off with wreck diving in Coron. Before flying out to Coron we decided to kill a few days in Manila. A city that seems to be misunderstood by the whole world, at least according to Carlos Celdran, who is a performance artist that has very deep knowledge in the history of the Philippines. If you visit Manila, I definitely recommend he’s tour Walk this Way that hopefully will open your eyes regarding the Philippines and Manila (in particular Intramuros).

Very excited about Coron and the wreck diving tomorrow

entry.title: Indonesia Here I Come
entry.content:
It’s been a couple of week since my last post, and that’s simply because I neither had the time nor the energy to write anything (and it’s also simply because I haven’t done anything worth writing about, I do however been quite active on Instagram).

Almost two weeks ago we (Hannah, me and John) left Hannah’s house in Brunei for a ten day road trip through Sabah. We took the car and drove north to the town ‘Kota Belud’. Now, the distance between Temburong and Kota Belud is around ~200 km. Normally (I define normally as back home in Sweden), you would drive that in like, two, three hours depending on the road/traffic. Well, down here it took us over 6 hours to drive that distance. It wasn’t actually that bad in the beginning, but the horrible traffic jam in Kota Kinabalu easily added two hours. After passing Kota Kinabaly we decided to go to my hidden gem right outside Kota Belud. Hannah and John (as me) liked Manana and stayed for two days before they decided to continue the trip north. Since I’ve already travelled around Sabah I took the chance to stay at Manana and wait for my friend Pauline who would arrive in a few days.

Turns out that my preference regarding accommodation wasn’t the same as my friend. We only stayed in the bungalow for two nights, lets just leave at that ;) Since Pauline is only here for a week we decided to stay in Kota Kinabalu (airport is there) to explore the luxurious hotels and the city itself. Turns out, that staying at a hotel, with a nice pool and a warm water shower isn’t that bad after all (I do however miss my bungalow).

To sum it up I would say that we had a good week that included, among other things,

  • Nice beach
  • Diving
  • Kayaking
  • Best curry ever
  • Bungalow and luxurious Hotels
  • Sunday afternoon hip hop, thug, bad ass motherfucker party at the dock
  • Food market and night market
  • Free beer at the local pub
  • Patrik’s quick course in Malay
  • Nasty fucking smells
  • Huge malls (both the “western” and the “local” ones)
  • Local bus
  • Malaysian Cinema
  • Archery
  • Really crowded and disgusting beach
  • Parasailing
  • Malaysian Day

Tomorrow Pauline is leaving for Hong Kong and I continue my journey in Asia by going to Indonesia (specifically Komodo). And yes, finally my body seem to be functioning quite normal again (that is, I can hear on both ears and no “visible open/infected wounds”), it only took 4 weeks, several medical clinics, two hospital visits and god knows how many antibiotic pills and whatever.

Note to self : Go to a specialist directly, dont bother with the “private clinics bullshit” or whatever. There is a few good ones, but mostly they are totally shit.

Seriously excited about going to Komodo (Indonesia), and the Philippines afterwords

entry.title: Brunei, Temburong and Bandar Seri Begawan
entry.content:
After staying at the Hidden Gem last week I decided to meet up my friend ‘Briini’ in Kota Kinabalu. We met on Perhentian Islands in the beginning of my journey and recently decided to visit our mutual friend Hannah (whom we also met on Perhentian Islands) in Brunei.

Hannah lives in the northern part of Brunei which is called Temburong. To be honest there isn’t really much to it in Temburong. They have some nice jungle and a river floating by, but other than that there is simply nothing for foreigners to do. We do however got to enjoy this really huge comfortable villa in the middle of the beautiful jungle. It’s about 150 square meters, has a pool and descent internet so I’m not complaining. I’m gonna stay here for about another week to see if I can get my coding mojo back (it’s on its way, especially since I’ve started coding on this new project). Hannah is way to nice though and keeps cooking and feeding us all the time. I seriously still find it so amazing that I have met all this fantastic friends.

The other day we went to Bandar Seri Begawan (which apparently has the longest capital name in the world) to do some “tour guides”. I don’t know if the capital itself was that special, but I did enjoy Kamopong Ayer (the water village) and The Royal Regalia Building.

Yesterday we got the pleasure of following Hannah to school which was an amazing experience on so many levels. Hannah is so fantastic with her children (she is actually fantastic in any way you can imagine) and you can see how the children just loves her. Being the ‘orang puti’ (white people) in a school full of kids ranging from the age of five to eleven is, lets say, quite interesting :)

This morning we said goodbye to ‘Briini’ since she is going back home to Switzerland in a few days. Saying goodbye is always hard as I mentioned in an earlier post, but I seriously feel truly blessed meeting so much new friends. I’m sure we will meet again ‘Briini’, and until then you will have a special place in my ‘hostel heart’ ;)

entry.title: Kota Kinabalu, Tampat Do Aman and the Hidden Gem
entry.content:
As a last stop before my two friends, Isabel & Luisa, were heading back to Germany we decided to hit the beaches. Borneo is full of nice beaches and Islands, however when it came to actually picking one we seemed to be in trouble.

We only had a few days so our options were somewhat limited, but we finally decided to head over to Kota Kinabalu and then continue north to the ‘tip of Borneo’. There are a couple of places up there but we decided to go with Tampat do aman, a jungle camp run by a guy called Howard Stanton. When we arrived in Kudat a taxi picked us up and took us to the camp where we were introduced to the place by a guy called Gilbert.

There isn’t really much to do in the actual camp so once we got there we directly headed down to the beach. The beach stretches over one kilometer and its white “powderish” sand is simply stunning. The water is crystal clear and the temperature is well above 30 degrees. We had the beach by ourselves for almost three days, and no one of us could understand why (still cant). If you want a getaway and love beaches, this is the place for you.

It’s a real shame that Isabel & Luisa had to go back to Germany, and although saying goodbye was really hard, I do appreciate the time we had together and I’ll always be grateful for you letting me in on your vacation - I seriously couldn’t have asked for a better start on Borneo.

❤


The hidden Gem
There is a small hidden gem near Kudat on the west coast of Borneo called Mañana. This little paradise is truly amazing and you won’t regret going here (call Nina first though to make sure she has available accommodation for you since it can be quite busy).

You will arrive by boat to a beach with some chalets and a small restaurant area, at the end of the beach a diving shop (bigfin divers) is located and operated by the fantastic couple Apec and Ella. The diving here is really good and luckily the coral reefs are still alive since these dive sites basically are untouched (the reason for this is simply that nobody has been operating in this area, you can go diving here both from Kota Kinabalu and Mantanini, but it will cost you and most people just don’t want to pay the price). Be sure to check the weather forecasts though since the weather here can be quite rough and even if you can go diving in rough weather the current can be very very strong which takes away a bit of the fun (personal opinion of course). Also, check out the Bigfin Divers Facebook page for their latest findings.

There is no cellphone reception nor wifi on Mañana which creates a really nice atmosphere in the “hangout area” (just make sure to inform family and friends that you won’t be reachable during the stay). I got to know some great people and I definitely had some good laughs at Mañana - this is a must stop if you are in the area and want some good relaxation combined with meeting some new friends.

Thanks for making my stay memorable,

  • Oliver and Rachel, Oliver, make sure you take good care of that beautiful girl of yours.
  • Wentworth - May’s, good luck with everything, give Avery my best (and some roti, he seemed to like it ;)).
  • Alison and Yvonne, thanks for the history lesson, I really appreciated the last night with you guys.
  • Victoria and ?, again, congratulations to your wedding, I wish you all the best. I’m so sorry but I forgot your husbands name, my deepest apologies :/

entry.title: Sukau, Kinabatangand and Osman = Aweseomesauce
entry.content:
Almost two weeks ago, before leaving the Perhentian Islands, we had gotten a number to a place called Osman’s Homestay. It was suppose to be quite cheap and apparently this “Osman Guy” knew all the right spots along Kinabatangan.

A day before leaving Sepilok I called Osman’s Homestay and asked them if we could come and stay with them for a few days, the lady agreed and sent us a pickup the next day.

When we arrived at the jetty in Sukau the lady that I’d been talking to over the phone a day earlier greets us with a big smile and directly tells us to jump into the boat. It doesn’t take long before you realise that she probably spent her whole life on this river, knowing both the river and the boat extremely well. I’ve never seen anybody controlling a boat like that. We arrived at their home a couple of minutes later and settled down for a few hours.

We decided to go for an afternoon ride on Kinabatangan, unfortunately I still wasn’t feeling that well so I didn’t really enjoy the ride. We did however see some long tail monkeys, hornbill birds, fishtails and a yellow ringed snake so the ride wasn’t bad, but sitting for hours in the sun when having a fever is really annoying. Osman’s family noticed that something was wrong though and took good care of me (gave me some magic pills that made the fever go away, winning).

Next day we went with Osman on an “elephant search”. The day before he had seen a big herd of elephants a couple of hours away so he knew they couldn’t be too far away (over two hours in a small boat feels pretty long though). Osman has been doing this for over ten years (taking tourists) and is well established among people, he is usually recruited by filming crews because he’s such a good spotter (for example David Attenborough and his film crew used Osman while making the Conquest of the skies documentary). He will take you to the places were nobody else goes and he will definitely point out things that you never would have seen by your self (seriously, he’s that good). After going north on Kinabatangan for almost two and a half hours, we finally caught up with the pygmy elephant herd (counted 40-50). It was truly a magic moment to see these beautiful animals playing around, eating grass and last but not least cooling them selves down in the river. We were totally alone, no other boats, no tourists, nothing - just us and the elephants. Osman simply smiles and tells us to enjoy the wild life.

On the way back we saw a lot of “resort tourist boats” that were packed with people - none of them got to see the elephant herd (simply because the resorts won’t go that extra mile). I strongly recommend the local homestay establishments if you want the best experience.

Before heading over to Kota Kinabalu we decided to go for a night ride on Kinabatangan as well. Mostly we wanted to see the “famous fireflies”, but it turns out that there’s a lot more interesting stuff to see at night than just fireflies. We saw quite a few crocodiles, owls, wild cats, huge rats, jumping fish, bats and lastly sleeping proboscis monkeys. My personal favourite however was the fireflies, it’s just so cool to see them light up as they do. Trees light up in the forest like decorated Christmas trees (seriously, looks like flashing trees). One could just sit there for hours and watch it.

entry.title: Flying to Sandakan and Into the Rainforest
entry.content:
After enjoying Kuching and it’s beautiful town, including the amazing food festival that just happened to take place during the nights we were there, we flew north to a town called Sandakan. From Sandakan we took a taxi to a small place called Sepilok.

Sepilok is most known for its Orangutan rehabilitation center which was located just a few minutes from our hotel. The Sepilok rehabilitation center is a park where they take care of orphaned orangutans until they are grown enough to take care of them selves, this usually takes about 10-12 years and requires a lot of effort. Now, taking care of orphaned orangutans and teaching them everything their mother were suppose to teach them is truly an awesome thing, one could however raise the question about how their mothers died in the first place, I’ll leave that one to the reader though. The park has “feeding times” at 10 am and 3 pm and you would want to be there at least 20 minutes earlier to get a descent view (it’s really crowded).

My personal favorite however was the Labuk Bay proboscis monkey sanctuary where you could see (and actually get really close to) the proboscis monkeys. If you are lucky enough you’ll also see the silver leaf monkey and the famous hornbill birds.

All in all, this was a great a day and we managed to see everything we wanted. Unfortunately me and Luisa got sick the other day so we’ve been struggling with fever and this fucking runny nose. It has been very annoying two days, but it finally seems to be heading in the right direction, knock on wood.

Now heading of to Sukau and Osman homestay for some real jungle experience.

entry.title: Cat City and the War Veteran
entry.content:
This morning we arrived at Kuching, the capital of Sarawak. We had to get up at 4am so we were pretty torn out when we arrived. We fought the tiredness though and decided to get to know the city a little better with a walk. It didn’t take long before we fell in love Kuching and it’s beautiful Sarawak river.

Sarawak River is amazingly cool and runs through the whole city acting as an important transport area. We decided to take one of the tour boats (for 20 ringit) which goes both ways on the river for an hour. The tour boat isn’t really “guided” since it’s only provided by a driver whom didn’t seem to show any interest at all in pointing out stuff for us. Luckily we met a guy called Charlie and his wife Chris who knew the city really well. Turns out that they go to Malaysia twice a year, and that Charlie is an old war veteran and was invited by the Malaysian Government this year to celebrate that 50 years had gone by since the conflict between Malaysia and Indonesia ended. Pretty interesting fella who definitely liked to talk (picture with him below).

We ended the day at the Black Bean who happened to serve the best coffee in town. Small, cozy coffee shop with all sorts of coffee and a very friendly staff. If you are up to it, why not enjoy the coffee with some sort of “local fishcake”, it’s suppose to be really good, I however, was not up for it. My friends seemed to like it though.

Lastly, we got totally lost when headed back to Beds Guest House and ended up walking for an hour instead of the “normal 10 minute walk”. Beds Guest House is btw an insanely good guest house with extremely (I mean hotel style) clean rooms and a very friendly staff that will help you with whatever you need. Price is good and we ended up paying 25 ringit each / per night for our own room on the loft. Right outside the guest house you will meet Annie who probably makes one of Kuching’s best Kolo mee, winning!

entry.title: Diving at Perhentian
entry.content:
When I arrived late afternoon on the tenth of July to Perhentian Islands I was terrified, seriously, absolutely terrified. I had planned to go diving with Angel Divers since a friend of a friend knew the owner. I arrived at the diveshop and was greeted by Rob (who’s currently a divemaster there) who asked me if I was up for some diving.

I nervously said that I was and that all I basically wanted to do on the Island was to dive. We decided to go diving in the morning and I went on looking for some accommodation. At the end of the beach there was an interesting place called the butterfly guesthouse where you “signed your self in”. If there was a key on the board, the room was free, and you could take it. No reception, no one to talk to or anything, just a key (if you were lucky, which I actually was, you could run into the guy running the place and he would show you your chalet). The condition of the chalets were pretty poor and unfortunately there was some animals (like bats and rats) hanging around. Even though these chalets provide the best view on the whole Island I only stayed there for a night. I guess I’m a little bit to comfortable for that kind of living. It’s a shame though that the place is falling a part since it’s so freaking cool. Later on I ended up staying directly on the beach in one of Mayas Guest House’s bungalows, which fitted me perfectly.

I did all my diving at Angel Divers and I met some really good friends. The first two weeks we were about ten people that got to know each other really well. This was an amazing experience for me, I still can’t believe how that many people ended up in the same place and everyone just got along. The weeks went by and people started to leave for new adventures. I hadn’t really thought about when to leave but I knew I was going to Borneo for some jungle tracking and a lot more diving. Luckily enough two German girls came by the shop to do some diving before they would hit Borneo. I nervously asked them if I could tag a long for a while since its much funnier to travel with people. They were more than happy to let me tag a long, and for that I’m eternally grateful. Luisa and Isabel are two amazing people and I’ve had so much fun with them (and will for another week or two). They are seriously the kindest friends, and even though I felt a little bit sad about leaving Perhentian, I couldn’t have gotten a better start on my Borneo adventure <3

Thanks again Angel Divers , see you soon again.
